column2: Cu–Te nanoparticles in a carbon matrix (generic)
column4: In situ–generated heterogeneity yields moderate ZT over a broader temperature range by scattering phonons via nanoscale features.
column12: Nanoscale heterogeneity for enhanced phonon scattering (effective at high T but less tuned for low T).

column3: Nanocomposite with tuned nanoparticle size & carbon matrix
column4: Adjusted processing (e.g., lower pyrolysis T, precursor design) tailors the nanoparticle size and matrix conductivity to maximize carrier transport and phonon scattering below 600 K.
column12: Engineered nanoscale heterogeneity optimized for low–temperature carrier and phonon management.

column4: Resonant doping within the established 18–electron framework can improve the power factor and lower thermal conductivity at higher T but needs retuning for low–T; performance uncertain.
column12: Band structure control via resonant dopants, though initially optimized for high–temperature regimes.

column4: Fine–tuning dopant levels/substitutions re–calibrates the conduction band and reduces thermal conductivity, targeting a robust low–temperature (T < 600 K) performance.
column12: Precise electronic structure tuning in an 18–electron system combined with reduced lattice thermal conductivity ideal for low T.

column4: Filler atoms induce “rattling” to scatter phonons, generating high ZT at elevated temperatures—but the dynamic rattling becomes “frozen” below 600 K, compromising low–T performance.
column12: Dynamic rattling modes that are very effective at high T but lose impact when thermal energies drop (now unsuited for T < 600 K).

column2: Bi₂Te₃ composite (with minor Sb₂Te₃ alloying components)
column4: Leverages the decades–long proven performance of Bi₂Te₃ at room/low temperatures; additional nanostructuring introduces interface scattering to further suppress phonons at T < 600 K.
column12: Combines intrinsic low–T efficiency of Bi₂Te₃ with engineered interface scattering—delivering exceptional performance and stability at low T.
